content.description: A fun TR with nice flow off the Tunnel Cake anchors on the face. Follow the large dip to the left then the flakes right and straight up. The move to the right halfway up may be a bit trickier if your fingers don't fit the undercling. As mentioned in the Tunnel Cake description, follow the obvious right weaknesses for another "easier 10."
content.location: Right end of the wall 10 ft right of Crinoid Process. Look for a right to left crescent that leads into a flake system.

content.description:
generally vertical climbing, see internet link. 

vainokodas.com/climbing/nmr…
content.location: left end of shelf, right and up from Crumbcake.

content.description: The right to left crack system is easy and provides a good approach to two TRs to the left.  The TRs are easier 10s and follow separate left and right weaknesses.
content.protection: Small trad rack to two inches.  Bolts and chains on the face just left of the crack finish.
content.location: The route is near a tree about 10 yards uphill and right of Tunnel Vision.

content.description: Climb up a large flake, clip a bolt and traverse right around a roof.  The climbing becomes much easier after the first third of the climb.
content.protection: Gear to two inches and one bolt.  Place additional gear because the rock is brittle.
content.location: The climb just left of Lazy Daze.  The start is a large flake.  Rap from the same anchor as Lazy Daze.

content.description: Interesting and balancy face climbing while protecting the thin crack system. The face to the left can also be toproped off the same anchors.
content.protection: Small cams and nuts and one bolt.
content.location: This climb is towards the west end of the cliff band, on a scalloped face.

content.description: The crux is near the bottom of the route.
content.protection: Trad gear to two inches.  Anchor at top.
content.location: The route is the crack just left of Redtail.  Rap the bolts and chains.

content.description: Sustained laybacking up a sharp flake system.
content.protection:
Small to medium gear. Bolted anchors (shares anchors with Black Diamond).  

  A toprope can be easily set up by by using the third class scramble to the left of the alcove.
content.location: This climb ascends the obvious flake system at the far east end of the cliff. This route, along with Black Diamond and Redtail are located in the alcove at the far east end of the cliff.

content.description:
This climb ascends the right trending smiley faced groove and up the overhanging headwall. Sustained and strenuous right off the ground. The only rest is on the ledge below the headwall.  

  The large chockstone on the headwall appears firmly lodged, and has been yarded on many times.
content.protection: Mixed protection. Four bolts and a crucial medium cam placement in a pocket.
content.location: This route, along with Black Diamond and Shark Crack are located in the alcove at the far east end of the cliff.

content.description: The crux is near the end of the climb after the bolt.  Be sure to place adequate gear at the start and finish of the climb.
content.protection: Trad gear to two inches plus one bolt.  Bolts and chain on top.
content.location: The route is the crack and pillar ten feet to the right of Redtail.  Rap from anchors.

content.description: This is a good beginning trad lead,  The hardest moves are nearer the ground but there is no specific crux.
content.protection: All gear, to three inches, with anchors and chains on the top.
content.location: The crack just left of Tunnel Vision.

content.description: Step up on a short slab, clip a bolt and climb up and left (the crux) to a crack.  Follow the crack to a ledge, clip another bolt and follow the weakness right to the anchor.  Place extra protection in the shallow limestone cracks.   The anchor provides access to a TR (5.10), through the huecos, to the right of the route.
content.protection: Small to medium gear and bolts.  Anchors and chains at top.
content.location: Start in a shallow corner a few feet to the right of Lost & Found.   Rap the route.

content.description: This climb ascends a hand/fist crack. The bottom ten feet is a little crumbly, but the climbing above is fun, with good jams.
content.protection: Medium to large gear. Bolted anchors.
content.location: This climb is 100 yards west of the alcove, and ascends a hand/fist crack.

content.description: Climb up and right clipping bolts then climb up a crack to the anchors.
content.protection: Bolts and gear (large cams for the top).  Anchors and chains at the top.
content.location: The route is right and uphill from Tunnel Springs.  Rap the route.

content.description: Climb over the obvious diamond shaped stone covered in black lichen and trend up and left to the same anchors as Shark Crack. Balancy face moves on crimps and thin fingers.
content.protection: Small wireds and small tcus. Shares bolted anchors with Shark Crack.
content.location: This route, along with Shark Crack and Redtail are located in the alcove at the far east end of the cliff.

content.description:
This area features 35-45' tall climbs on moderate quality limestone. All routes have bolted anchors, but all require gear placement unless otherwise noted. The routes are generally sustained and the rock is sharp.    

  The best season for this northwest facing cliff is summer mornings(shade until ~2:00 p.m.) or spring/fall afternoons (late afternoon sun). This area provides a convenient opportunity for a half day of climbing in close proximity to Albuquerque with the opportunity for gear leads.  

  The view from the crag is beautiful. You will generally see few people, mostly a few local residents walking their dogs.  

  The minimum equipment for this area is a 90' gym rope, 8-10 draws, and a half rack (single set cams and nuts). Gear is generally medium to small, and sometimes tricky. 

  This crag is in the wilderness boundary. All bolts were hand drilled. Please observe a wilderness ethic if establishing new routes.  

  There is limited opportunity to safely set top ropes (the top is loaded with rocks on a steep slope and many trees have died due to bark beetle). Unless noted in the route description as safe to set a top rope - leading is recommended.
